text: I'm looking to solve an advection-type PDE using `DiffEqOperators` , ideally in 2D (spatially). While it may be counter productive, I am looking to not use method of lines in the solution. Would this be a valid use of `DiffEqOperators`? The docs/examples seem to be spread out over DEO, MTK, and DifferentialEquations. Using MTK would be great, as I do not deal with PDEs much, but since I am looking for a concrete-tized representation of the problem it appears that working directly in DEO would be best? Any insights would be appreciated!

elements.text: I'm looking to solve an advection-type PDE using

DiffEqOperators

? The docs/examples seem to be spread out over DEO, MTK, and DifferentialEquations. Using MTK would be great, as I do not deal with PDEs much, but since I am looking for a concrete-tized representation of the problem it appears that working directly in DEO would be best? Any insights would be appreciated!

text: Could you share some more information about the equation you are trying to solve?

elements.text: Could you share some more information about the equation you are trying to solve?

text: I am also new to DiffEqOperators, so I don't know if I can help you, but I am also interested in similar problems :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I am also new to DiffEqOperators, so I don't know if I can help you, but I am also interested in similar problems

text:
along the lines of:
`\del_u/\del_t - F(x) * \del_u/del_x = 0`, `u(0,x) = g(x)`.

elements.text: along the lines of:
\del_u/\del_t - F(x) * \del_u/del_x = 0

text: which, if discretized in space, `u(t,x)` could be solved by `g(x)` evaluated along trajectories of `dx/dt = F(x)`

elements.text: which, if discretized in space,
u(t,x)
could be solved by
g(x)
evaluated along trajectories of
dx/dt = F(x)

text: Ah okay. So In DiffEqOperators, you might be interested in  `UpwindDifference`  Unfortunately, I think it is not yet tested. I tried experimenting with it a week ago.

elements.text: Ah okay. So In DiffEqOperators, you might be interested in
UpwindDifference
Unfortunately, I think it is not yet tested. I tried experimenting with it a week ago.

text: I am curious to know why you are not looking at method of lines type solutions

elements.text: I am curious to know why you are not looking at method of lines type solutions

text: I think using DiffEqOperators (i.e. a finite difference type approach) would result in a method of lines type of solution -- effectively you have converted the PDE into a system of ODEs for each grid point and you can use a suitable time integration scheme.

elements.text: I think using DiffEqOperators (i.e. a finite difference type approach) would result in a method of lines type of solution -- effectively you have converted the PDE into a system of ODEs for each grid point and you can use a suitable time integration scheme.

text: MOL is always there: you always have to phrase it as a discretization in time at some point. Whether you call an ODE solver or write the loop you still had an ODE

elements.text: MOL is always there: you always have to phrase it as a discretization in time at some point. Whether you call an ODE solver or write the loop you still had an ODE

text: Thanks for the info and help, guys. I take it that if I want to discretize/finite-diff the time dimension as well a different library would be better suited than DEO?

elements.text: Thanks for the info and help, guys. I take it that if I want to discretize/finite-diff the time dimension as well a different library would be better suited than DEO?

text: you can represent that by DEO, just do it on the time dimension. No issues there. It's not usually not a good method.

elements.text: you can represent that by DEO, just do it on the time dimension. No issues there. It's not usually not a good method.

text: okay cool, any chance you know of any examples that do something like this? there is only an "official" heat-eq example, although I have found a number of snippets in various issues/PRs/etc.

text: also, Chris, if I want to generate this subpar representation, would you recommend going at it directly through DEO, or utilize MTK to set it up?

elements.text: also, Chris, if I want to generate this subpar representation, would you recommend going at it directly through DEO, or utilize MTK to set it up?

text:
> also, Chris, if I want to generate this subpar representation, would you recommend going at it directly through DEO, or utilize MTK to set it up?
That depends on how deep you want to do. If you want the easy thing, just ask MTK to do it for you. Deeper, you want to use DEO
